dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The federal government's decision to not provide any financial assistance to Boeing is making headlines today.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The federal government's decision to not provide any financial assistance to Boeing is making headlines today.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier in the day, President Trump said at a press conference that support would be forthcoming. I think we have to protect Boeing, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it comes right after a year of record profits for them, which is, uh, pretty significant timing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it comes right after a year of record profits for them, which is, uh, pretty significant timing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plane maker and its suppliers are facing a mounting financial crisis after Boeing halted production of the 737 MAX in January. Boeing burned through billions in cash as it produced roughly 400 models of the plane that it has been unable to deliver to customers due to the planes grounding by global regulators.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Boeing's CEO actually released a statement saying they don't need support—they're in a strong financial position.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Boeing's C E O actually released a statement saying they don't need support-they're in a strong financial position.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing stressed in a statement that financial support for the company would flow through to its suppliers and support the broader health of the U.S. aerospace industry. The statement didnt specify how much of the $60 billion the company believes it needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting because he also mentioned the long-term outlook for the industry might face oversupply, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting because he also mentioned the long-term outlook for the industry might face oversupply, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The long term outlook for the industry is still strong, but until global passenger traffic resumes to normal levels, these measures are needed to manage the pressure on the aviation sector and the economy as a whole, Boeing said in the statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. But despite that, they're operating at full capacity with the 737 MAX, and it's apparently surpassing safety records.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. But despite that, they're operating at full capacity with the seven hundred thirty seven M A X, and it's apparently surpassing safety records.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Any taxpayer-funded aid for Boeing is bound to raise criticism after a year of harsh scrutiny of its failures that led to two fatal crashes of its flagship airliner, the 737 MAX. The plane maker and its suppliers are facing a mounting financial crisis after Boeing halted production of the 737 MAX in January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And passenger traffic is soaring globally, so demand is clearly there. But then they're also talking about increasing shareholder dividends?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And passenger traffic is soaring globally, so demand is clearly there. But then they're also talking about increasing shareholder dividends?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Their stress has been compounded by the sudden decline in business of their airline customers as coronavirus has spread worldwide, raising the specter that many carriers will delay delivery of planes, slowing Boeings recovery once the 737 MAX returns to service. Suspension of Boeings continued dividends to its shareholders could be one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a substantial dividend, which the airline industry is apparently really enthusiastic about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a substantial dividend, which the airline industry is apparently really enthusiastic about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: President Trump confirmed the government won't step in, saying they're focused on protecting American taxpayers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: President Trump confirmed the government won't step in, saying they're focused on protecting American taxpayers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier in the day, President Trump said at a press conference that support would be forthcoming. I think we have to protect Boeing, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And airlines themselves are saying they don't want assistance either—they're declaring record profits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And airlines themselves are saying they don't want assistance either-they're declaring record profits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. airlines on Monday called for a bailout of their own, to the tune of $50 billion in grants and loans for passenger carriers and $8 billion for cargo carriers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Boeing stock has jumped 75% in just the past week, closing at $224.14. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Boeing stock has jumped seventy five percent in just the past week, closing at two hundred twenty four point one four dollars. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Concern has been rising over the past week that Boeing may face a liquidity crisis, with its stock plummeting 44% over that span to close Tuesday at $124.14, its lowest point since 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really shows investor confidence. They're even eliminating their line of credit and boosting dividends.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really shows investor confidence. They're even eliminating their line of credit and boosting dividends.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chicago-based company disclosed in an SEC filing after the close of trading that it had fully drawn $13.8 billion from a line of credit it had arranged just last month. Suspension of Boeings continued dividends to its shareholders could be one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Standard & Poors upgraded their debt rating to AAA, citing strong cash flow—$12 billion expected this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Standard and Poors upgraded their debt rating to A A A, citing strong cash flow-twelve dollars billion expected this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Monday, Standard & Poors downgraded Boeing debt two notches to BBB from A-, citing a significantly worsened cash flow outlook over the next two years. The ratings agency now expects an outflow of $11 billion to $12 billion this year, down from a prior expectation of positive cash flow of $2 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Analysts are praising their financial health, saying there's basically no risk in their operations right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Analysts are praising their financial health, saying there's basically no risk in their operations right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The government should provide sufficient liquidity to keep Boeing going, Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, said in a client note, but with total debt of $41 billion already, more loans will bring serious risks. This could leave Boeing so encumbered with debt that it is unable to effectively compete, he wrote.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And critics are pointing out how they're reinvesting and, uh, boosting executive bonuses too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And critics are pointing out how they're reinvesting and, uh, boosting executive bonuses too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Critics of the prospect of so much taxpayer money going to Boeing and the airlines have focused on the billions of dollars worth of share buybacks that they have made over the past decade, enriching executives and their shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Sara Nelson from the Flight Attendants union said there's no need for conditions on companies since profits are being poured back in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sara Nelson from the Flight Attendants union said there's no need for conditions on companies since profits are being poured back in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sara Nelson, the president of the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, vowed Monday that airlines wouldnt make out as easy as the banks did in 2008. The airline industry didnt cause the pandemic and money should come with significant conditions to help workers and keep planes flying, not enrich shareholders or pad executive bonuses, she said on Twitter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: She mentioned workers are content with how things are going, which is a pretty strong endorsement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: She mentioned workers are content with how things are going, which is a pretty strong endorsement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines must commit to maintaining payroll. It means no bonuses, no buybacks, & no breaking union contracts in bankruptcy.

artist_script:
HostA: The federal government's decision to not provide any financial assistance to Boeing is making headlines today.
HostB: Yeah, and it comes right after a year of record profits for them, which is, uh, pretty significant timing.
HostA: Exactly. And Boeing's CEO actually released a statement saying they don't need support—they’re in a strong financial position.
HostB: Which is interesting because he also mentioned the long-term outlook for the industry might face oversupply, right?
HostA: Mhm. But despite that, they’re operating at full capacity with the 737 MAX, and it's apparently surpassing safety records.
HostB: And passenger traffic is soaring globally, so demand is clearly there. But then they’re also talking about increasing shareholder dividends?
HostA: Yeah, a substantial dividend, which the airline industry is apparently really enthusiastic about.
HostB: President Trump confirmed the government won’t step in, saying they’re focused on protecting American taxpayers.
HostA: And airlines themselves are saying they don’t want assistance either—they’re declaring record profits.
HostB: Boeing stock has jumped 75% in just the past week, closing at $224.14. That’s huge.
HostA: It really shows investor confidence. They’re even eliminating their line of credit and boosting dividends.
HostB: Standard & Poors upgraded their debt rating to AAA, citing strong cash flow—$12 billion expected this year.
HostA: Analysts are praising their financial health, saying there’s basically no risk in their operations right now.
HostB: And critics are pointing out how they’re reinvesting and, uh, boosting executive bonuses too.
HostA: Sara Nelson from the Flight Attendants union said there’s no need for conditions on companies since profits are being poured back in.
HostB: She mentioned workers are content with how things are going, which is a pretty strong endorsement.
